variant.question: The difference between MEL and MMEL

options.text: MMEL Established by manufacture, MEL established by operator
MMEL Established by operator, MEL established by manufacture
MMEL established by state of authority, MEL established by operator
MEL established by state of authority, MMEL established by operator

variant.question:
The Master Minimum Equipment List (MMEL) defines the equipment which can be inoperative when undertaking a flight and the conditions under which this allowance can be accepted
 This MMEL is drawn up by

options.text: the manufacturer and approved by the certification authority.
the certification authority.
the operator and approved by the certification authority
the operator from a main list drawn up by the manufacturer

variant.question: According to EU Air Operations Regulations, who is responsible for amending the MEL after any applicable change to the MMEL, and within what timeframe?

options.text: The operator, within acceptable, defined timescales.
The manufacturer immediately following publication of an applicable Airworthiness Directive.
The Competent Authority of the State of Registration before a return to flight.
The Competent Authority, within acceptable, defined timescales.

variant.question: The Minimum Equipment List (MEL) defines the equipment on which certain in-flight failures can be allowed and the conditions under which this allowance can be accepted. The MEL is drawn up by:

options.text: the operator and may be more restrictive than the Master Minimum Equipment List (MMEL).
the operator and may be less restrictive than the Master Minimum equipment List (MMEL).
the manufacturer and may be less restrictive than the Master Minimum equipment List (MMEL).
the manufacturer and may be more restrictive than the Master Minimum Equipment List (MMEL).
The operator
The Authority of the state of manufacture
The manufacturer
The Authority of the state of registration

variant.question: An acceptable timescale for submitting the amended MEL to the competent authority is ___ from the effective date specified in the approved change to the MMEL.

options.text: 90 days
30 days
15 days
60 days

variant.question: The minimum equipment list (MEL) gives the equipment which can be inoperative when undertaking a flight and the additional procedures to be observed accordingly. This list is prepared by:

options.text: the operator, and it is inserted in the Operations Manual.
the manufacturer, and it is inserted in the Operations Manual.
the operator, and it is appended to the Flight Manual.
the manufacturer, and it is appended to the Flight Manual.

variant.question: The field of application of the Minimum Equipment List (MEL) is defined by a phase of flight operation. The commander must use the limitations provided by the MEL:

options.text: at the parking area prior to the aircraft taxiing.
prior to the aircraft take-off.
until the aircraft has come to a complete stop at the end of the flight.
at any time during the flight.

variant.question: The MMEL is compiled by the:

options.text: Manufacturer
Operator
Authority of the state of manufacture
Authority of the state of registration

variant.question: When the MMEL is changed how long before it must be in the MEL?

options.text: 90 days
120 days
60 days
30 days
a limitation on the duration of operations with inoperative equipment as listed in the aircraft Minimum Equipment List (MEL)
the time interval after which an aircraft certificate of release to service expires, and a further release to service check will have to be carried out.
the maximum interval before a maintenance release to service becomes invalid, after which further certification is required.
the maximum interval between major servicing as stated in the operator's Maintenance Management Exposition.

variant.question: What is the relationship between MEL and MMEL?

options.text: The master minimum equipment list can be less restricting than the minimum equipment list.
The master minimum equipment list is based on the minimum equipment list.
The master minimum equipment list is more restricting than the minimum equipment list.
The master minimum equipment list refers to ground operations and the minimum equipment list refers to flight operations.

variant.question: Who is responsible for amending the MEL after any applicable change to the MMEL, and what is the timescale? (Refer to EASA AIR OPS regulations)

options.text: The operator, within the acceptable timescales.
The manufacturer, immediately following the publication of an airworthiness directive (AD).
The competent authority of the state of registry, before a return to flight.
The competent authority, within the acceptable timescales.

variant.question: The operator shall include in the OM a MEL which shall be approved by the authority of...

options.text: the country of the operator.
the country where the aircraft was manufactured.
none, because an approval is not required.
the country where the aircraft is operated.

variant.question: With regards to the MEL, which of the following statements is true?

options.text: The MEL may permit the Captain to accept an aircraft for operation with unserviceable or missing equipment.
Missing or unserviceable equipment may be deferred indefinitely.
MEL considerations apply during all phases of flight.
The MEL is produced by the aircraft manufacturer.

variant.question: Can an operator use the MMEL instead of MEL?

options.text: Yes, if it’s approved by the competent authority.
No, because MMEL is never approved by the competent authorities since all the airlines will create their own MEL.
No, the operators cannot refer to the manufacturer’s MMEL.
Yes, if the pilots have agreed on terms of the operator’s MEL.

variant.question: Following breaches of operational procedures which have been identified by the competent authority from its oversight programme (i.e. ramp inspections), who is responsible for completing checks and corrective actions?

options.text: The operator.
The competent authority.
The member state.
ICAO.

variant.question:
During the pre-flight preparation, a pilot who is operating a Commercial Air Transport flight with passengers, notices a fault with the only GPS receiver on board. The pilot has access to both the MEL and the MMEL, and finds the notes as shown below. How should the effect of the fault be addressed?MMEL: May be inoperative provided it is NOT required for navigation. 
 MEL: May be inoperative for VFR-by-day only; or; positioning flights if NOT required for navigation.

options.text: This flight may be conducted as planned if it is daylight and the flight is planned according to VFR only.
The restriction in the MMEL applies because this is the master document produced by the aeroplane manufacturer.
The pilot may conduct the flight with NO restrictions if the flight remains in VMC and alternative means for navigation are used.
Restrictions in the MEL are less strict than the MMEL and therefore the MEL must be used in this case.
